transcription: #### Classic Mac 'n' Cheese Prep: 20 minutes Cook: 20 minutes Serves: 6 to 8

Cook 6 oz. Ronzoni Elbow Macaroni according to package directions, drain. Bring 1 (10-oz.) container refrigerated light alfredo sauce, 2/3 cup chicken broth and 1 tsp. dry mustard to a boil. Reduce heat and stir in 11/2 cups shredded sharp Cheddar cheese, a little at a time, stirring until cheese is melted, then stir in macaroni. Transfer to a greased 9-inch baking dish. Stir together 1/4 cup panko bread crumbs and 3 tbsp. grated or shredded Parmesan cheese. Sprinkle over top and broil for 5 minutes or until top is golden brown.

transcription: - . To Fry: Place approximately 2" of oil in deep fryer or saucepan. Heat to 375". Securely attach two molds to handle and immerse in hot oil until thoroughly heated. Lift iron out and shake off excess oil (or blot on paper toweling). Dip iron into batter only to the depth of the molds. Avoid getting batter on top of molds. Immerse molds into hot oil, covering completely. When foamy bubbling stops, or Rosettes are a delicate brown, lift iron out, allowing excess oil to drip back into fryer. To remove Rosette, gently tap on top of mold with a wooden spoon. Before making additional Rosettes, reheat iron as necessary. (Iron must be hot!)
- If excess batter adheres to top of mold, fry as usual, then gently remove excess with knife for easier release.
- If batter will not adhere to molds, oil may be either too hot or too cold. Check with thermometer and adjust accordingly.
- If first Rosette Cookies are not crisp, thin batter with a little milk. Also check the temperature of oil and molds.
- Cool, with the more open side down, on rack or paper towelling.
- To store: Layer cooled cookies nor more than 3 deep in air-tight container. May be frozen.

transcription: Eggehilada: Scramble eggs and spoon down the center of a tortilla. Roll up the tortilla, top it off with enchilada sauce and a drift of sour cream. Scatter some green onion on for a finishing touch. Simple and centsible.
The Prairie Dog: Fry an egg sunnyside up and, while it's frying, toast a split English muffin half and grill a split frank. Layer it all with a slice of cheese and then enjoy.

The Eggburger: Scramble an egg or two, or fry them over easy, then serve on a burger bun. Top with your choice of the workscheese, mushrooms, lettuce, tomato, onion, bacon, catsup, olives, almost anything. A mansized meal for mini-money.

Quiche: follow a basic recipe and vary it anyway you like. The greatest thing about a quiche is that it is a perfect vehicle for leftovers. You can use chopped cooked chicken, fish, ham, or almost any shredded cheeses. Or chopped cooked vegetables such as green beans, carrots, broccoli, asparagus, cauliflower,  $potatoes -$

1-1/2 cups granulated sugar 1-1/2 cups packed brown sugar 1/4 teaspoon salt 1/4 teaspoon baking soda I cup sour cream I tablespoon light corn syrup 2 tablespoons butter or margarine I teaspoon vanilla 2 cups pecans Combine sugars, salt, baking soda, sour cream and corn syrup in large heavy saucepan. Cook over moderate heat to thread stage (230° on candy thermometer), stirring constantly. Remove from heat and beat in butter, vanilla and pecans. Cool to warm, then beat until mixture begins to lose its sheen. Working rapidly to prevent candy from setting, drop by teaspoonfuls onto waxed paper. If candy begins to set. return to heat or put pot in bowl of boiling water until mixture is soft and smooth. When set and cool, remove pralines to a tray. Makes about 36.

Add an elegant accent to dining with a fresh mushroom appetizer or salad course. You can serve it anytime because a ready supply of fresh mushrooms is available yearround. When selecting mushrooms, look for caps tucked down close to the stems. Keep mushrooms lightly covered in the refrigerator for up to two days. Before using, rinse the mushrooms and pat dry. Cut off the stem ends.
1 pound large fresh mushrooms, about 11/2 inches in diameter
Lettuce leaves **Pitted ripe olives Prosciutto ham Cherry tomatoes**

With small, sharp knife cut stem out of each mushroom, leaving a smooth cavity. (Refrigerate and save stems for another use.) Coat mushrooms with lemon juice; let dry on paper toweling. In mixer bowl combine cream cheese,

butter or margarine, parsley, chives, and fines herbes; beat with electric mixer till light and fluffy. Fill mushroom cavities with cream cheese mixture; sprinkle tops with additional snipped parsley, if desired.
Arrange mushroom caps on lettuce lined salad plates; add ripe olives, prosciutto, and cherry tomatoes. Makes 8 appetizer servings.

Cut mushrooms in 1/8-inch slices. In screw-top jar combine olive oil, lemon juice, mustard, salt, and pepper. Cover jar and shake well. Pour mixture over mushrooms, tossing gently to coat. Let mixture stand at room temperature for 1 hour, stirring occasionally. Serve mushrooms on lettuce leaves. Makes 3 or 4 salad servings.

- 1. Put flank steak on a small cookie sheet; freeze for 15 minutes to "firm up" for easier slicing. Then cut steak in half lengthwise. Cut each half into  $\frac{1}{8}$ -inch slices.
- 2. Mix chili sauce, soy sauce, sherry, cornstarch, ginger and red pepper flakes in a small bowl; reserve.
- 3. Heat 1 tablespoon of the oil in wok or large skillet. Add garlic and green onions; stir-fry 1 minute. Remove to a bowl with slotted spoon.
- 4. Add remaining 2 tablespoons oil to wok. Add steak slices, a third at a time, and stir-fry quickly until meat loses its red color. Place in bowl with green onions.
- 5. Add chili sauce mixture to wok; heat until bubbly-hot. Stir in meat and green onions; cook and stir until chili sauce mixture coats meat and green onion.

transcription: ## I package active dry yeast
- % cup (8%-oz. can) drained, chopped, sliced peaches (reserve syrup)
Generously grease bottom and sides of 13x9-inch baking pan. In large mixing bowl, soften yeast in warm water. (No need to sift flour; measure by lightly

spooning into cup and leveling off.) Add 1 cup flour, sugar, salt, shortening, milk and egg to dissolved yeast; mix well. Stir in remaining flour to form a stiff dough. Knead on floured surface until dough is smooth and no longer sticky, about 3 minutes. Place in greased bowl, turning to grease top. Cover; let rise in warm place until light and doubled in size, 1 to 11/2 hours. Punch down dough. Roll out on floured surface to 18x12-inch rectangle. Brush with 2 tablespoons reserved peach syrup; sprinkle dry gelatin over lengthwise half of dough. Randomly spoon peaches over gelatin. Fold plain half over peach half; seal edges. Cut into twelve 11/2-inch strips. Twist each strip 2 times. Place in prepared pan, forming 2 rows of 6 twists each; press both ends of each strip firmly to bottom of pan. Cover; let rise in warm place until light and doubled in size, 30 to 45 minutes. Bake at 350° for 25 to 30 minutes until golden brown. Prepare Topping; pour warm Topping over warm twists. Serve warm or cool.

Hello! It's me, Glenn Seavey, your Hawaiian Sales Consultant at Larry Genere Ford. As you probably know, I am originally from Hawaii. I love the food and the culture and would like to share this love with you. The recipe below for Basic Adobo is one of my favorites. It is a Phillipino dish that is very easy to make and "ono" good.

Basic Adobo Ingredients: 3 1b. chicken thighs or 3 1b. pork butt 1/2 cup vinegar 1/4 cup soy sauce 3 cloves of garlic 1/4 teaspoon salt 1/4 teaspoon peppercorns, crushed 1 bay leaf, crushed Cut chicken pieces in half if thighs are large. If using pork, cut into 1 1/2 inch pieces. In a saucepan, combine all ingredients. Let stand for 1 to 3 hours. Bring to a boil. Cover, lower heat, and simmer for 30 minutes (45) minutes for pork). Remove cover and simmer 15 more minutes or until liquid evaporates and chicken/pork is lightly browned. Makes 6 servings.
I would recommend preparing some white rice as a side dish. Please call me after you prepare this dish and tell me what you think... or just bring a little by so I can sample your version. Enjoy!
Sincerely, Glenn Seavey Larry Geweke Ford  $530 - 821 - 2121$

Also known as tutti-frutti, fruit crock or romertopf. Start this add-to potpourri when the first fruit of spring or summer is available. As other fruits come in season, add them to the crock. Mixture will take several weeks to develop. It is very important to use only perfect, firm, ripe fruits; to wash and dry them well; to sterilize the crock and let the mixture ferment in a cool, dry place (not in the refrigerator or in a hot kitchen). This potpourri makes a sweet sauce that's delicious on ice cream, plain cake or puddings.

Next day or as berries are available, stir in one of the suggested berries and 1 cup sugar. Cover with cheesecloth and return to cool storage place. The next few days repeat with remaining berries, adding I cup sugar with each. When all berries are added, cover with cheesecloth and store in cool, dry place at least 2 weeks, preferably I month, or until fermented. #### Microwave Jam and Jelly Guidelines (Yield: One-half the amount of the original recipe)
- 1. Use one-half of the amounts called for in the recipe folder inside the pectin box. (One-half package of MCP Pectin measures 21/2 tablespoons.)
- 2. Sift sugar before measuring to break down any lumps that may not dissolve during cooking. Measure sugar into dry bowl to be added later.
- 3. Measure fruit or juice into 3- or 4-quart glass bowl. Add lemon juice if called for.
- 4. Stir the MCP Pectin into fruit or juice, and microwave on high until mixture boils throughout (about 8-9 minutes). Stir midway through cooking time.
- 5. Quickly stir in premeasured sugar. Mix well. Add 1/8 teaspoon margarine to reduce foaming.
- 6. Microwave on high until the jam or jelly tests done (about 7-8 minutes). To determine doneness, use one of the tests listed below.
- 7. Skim foam. Pour and seal according to directions on recipe folder.
## **Spoon or Sheet Doneness Test for Jellies**

- Dip a cool metal spoon in the jelly mixture. Raise the spoon above the kettle and turn the spoon so the syrup runs off the side of the spoon. If the syrup forms two drops that flow together and fall off the spoon as one sheet, the jelly should be done.
- Refrigerator Doneness Test for Jams Pour a small amount of hot jam on a cold plate, and place it on the top shelf of a refrigerator for 2-3 minutes. If
- One misture jells, it should be done.

## What to do if your cooked jam or jelly doesn't set
- 1. Prepare jars as directed in Cooked Jam directions.
- 2. Slowly stir contents of 1 box MCP Fruit Pectin into 3/4 cup boiling water in medium bowl. Let stand 10 minutes, stirring occasionally to dissolve pectin.

- 3. Remake batch: Place unset jam or jelly in large saucepot. Bring to full rolling boil (a boil that doesn't stop bubbling when stirred) on high heat, stirring constantly. Add Pectin Mixture. Return to a full rolling boil. Remove from heat. Skim off any foam. Ladle into prepared jars. Follow boiling water bath method to process jars.

- 1 Lb. sole fillets, fresh or frozen
- 2 Tbs clarified butter, or salad oil

Defrost frozen fillets in their package. Wipe fish with a damp cloth, cut into serving portions, and arrange in a layer in a well-buttered baking dish. Heat the oil over medium heat and saute the onion to a golden translucence. Stir in the flour and conk and stir until smoothly blended and bubbly. Add the salt and pepper, and in a slow and steady stream, stir in the cream, stirring constantly until thickened. Remove from heat and slowly stir in wine until blended. Pour the sauce over the fish. Bake in a preheated 350°F, oven for about 1/2 hour or until the flesh flakes to a fork. Spoon the sauce from the pan over the fish from time to time, keeping it well distributed over the fish.
- Cup mushrooms, sliced  $\frac{1}{2}$ Salt and pepper

Butter a baking dish and sprinkle the scallions and mushrooms on the bottom. Arrange the fish fillets over the vegetables, covering the thin part of each fillet with the thick part of another (to prevent overcooking). Season the fish and sprinkle with wine and lemon juice. Top with cheese and bread crumbs and pour butter over top. Wrinkle a piece of waxed paper, wet it, and spread it directly on the fish. Bake at 400° for 7 minutes. Remove waxed paper and bake 5 minutes longer. Serves 4-6.
- 2 Lbs. large red snapper fillets or steaks

Wipe the fillets with a damp cloth. Combine dry ingredients. Dip the fillets in the milk and dredge in the flour and cornmeal mixture. Heat the oil in a heavy skillet and quickly brown the fillets on both sides. Reduce the heat. Arrange half of the capers on the fish, cover with tomato slices, and put the remaining capers on top. Salt and pepper generously. Add wine to the pan. Cover and cook over medium heat for about 20 minutes, or until flesh flakes to a fork. Move to a serving platter. Serve immediately. garnished with additional capers.

any food gift. It is both a courtesy and a safety measure, since any food or ingestible may hold some risk for triggering an allergic reaction.

To make a homemade liqueur gift more special, include a set of cordial glasses. They will be a subtle reminder that liqueurs should be consumed in small amounts. A few sips (about 1 ounce) in a miniature goblet is an appropriate serving for these sweet drinks.
You might also include a food gift and recipe that use the liqueur. As an example, we've adapted a simple pound cake recipe for holiday gift-giving.
Who knows, if your homemade gifts are a hit this season, you may want to plan for next year and take advantage of summer's bounty to brew up some blueberry, peach or raspberry liqueurs.

Directions: Shake together 1/4 cup Planters Oil, sherry, soy sauce, garlie, and ginger until well mixed. Pour over sliced beef. Marinate in reingerator for 1 to 2 hours.

In a large saucepan, heat 3 tablespoons Planters Oil. Brown meat, reserving marinade. Remove and set aside. Add 1 tablespoon Planters Oil to pan. Sauté celery and carrots until celery turns bright green. Remove and set aside. Now, add 1 tablespoon Planters Oil to pan. Sauté mushrooms until golden. Add reserved marinade, beef stock, beef, celery, and carrots. Bring to a boil. Reduce heat; cover and simmer 15 minutes or until beef is tender. Stir in water chestnuts. Combine cornstarch with a little broth until smooth; stir into hot broth. Cook until thickened. Serve over hot cooked rice.
## **STIR-FRY CHICKEN WITH MANDARIN ORANGES BONELESS CHICKEN BREASTS** Yield 4 servings (found in the Regular Poultry Section)

1 lb. Boneless Chicken Breasts cooking oil gingerroot (1 tsp.) soy sauce fresh pea pods (2 cups) OR cornstarch orange peel (1 tsp.) one 16 oz. pkg. frozen pea pods 11 oz. can mandarin orange sections orange juice Start to thaw the pea pods if you bought frozen ones.

Cut chicken into bite-sized strips. Prepare: 1 tsp. grated gingerroot 1 tsp. grated orange peel Drain: canned orange sections. Blend: 2 Tbsp. soy sauce into 2 tsp. cornstarch. Add: grated orange peel  $\frac{1}{2}$  cup orange juice Set aside. Preheat a wok or large skillet over high heat and keep it hot while cooking. Add: 2 Tbsp. cooking oil Stir-Fry the gingerroot for 30 seconds. Add: pea pods and stir-fry 2 minutes if fresh, 1 minute if frozen/thawed. Remove the pea pods. If necessary, add a little more oil. Stir-fry half of the chicken 2-3 minutes, or until browned. Remove the chicken and then repeat with the other uncooked half of the chicken. Return the previously cooked meat to the wok/skillet so that all of it is there. Stir soy sauce mixture into the chicken and cook, stirring, until thickened and bubbly. Add: pea pods Cover and cook 1 minute more. Remove from heat.

In large mixer bowl, dissolve yeast in warm water. Add milk, sugar, salt, nutmeg, cinnamon, eggs, shortening and 2 cups of the flour. Blend 1/2 minute on low speed, scraping bowl constantly, Beat 2 minutes medium speed, scraping bowl occasionally. Stir in remaining flour until smooth, scraping side of bowl. Cover, let rise in warm place until double, 50 to 60 minutes.

Turn dough onto well-floured cloth-covered board; roll around lightly to coat with flour. (Dough will be soft to handle.) With floured stockinet-covered rolling pin, gently roll dough about 1/2 inch thick. Cut with floured 21/2-inch doughnut cutter (or cut both ends out of a can about  $2\frac{1}{2}$  inches in diameter and use about a 1-inch cutter for centers).
Lift doughnuts carefully with spatula and place 2 inches apart on greased baking sheet. Brush doughnuts with melted butter. Cover; let rise until double, about 20 minutes.

2 cups confectioners' sugar 1/2 cup Pillsbury's Best Flour (Regular or Instant Blending) 1/2 teaspoon baking powder  $\frac{1}{2}$  cup (3 to 4) egg whites 2 cups chopped walnuts 1/2 cup chopped dried apricots

Cream together outter, margarine and powdered sugar. Beat in egg and vanilla. Combine flour, soda, cream of tartar and salt and add to creamed mixture. Mix well. Divide dough in half. Form each half into 2-inch round roll. Wrap in waxed paper or aluminum foil. Chill in refrigerator or freezer. Slice 3%-inch thick. Bake on ungreased cookie sheet in 350 degree oven 8 to 10 minutes. Cool on rack. Makes about 7 dozen. (Rolls can be stored in refrigerator, sliced and baked when desired.)

In mixing bowl, combine sugar, flour, baking powder and egg whites. Add walnuts and apricots; mix well. Drop by teaspoonfuls onto well-greased cookie, sheets. Bake at 325° for 15 to 18 minutes. Variations:
Substitute 1 cup peanut butter pieces for the apricots. Substitute 1 cup flaked coconut for the apricots. Add V<sub>s</sub> teaspoon cinna-
mon and 1/s teaspoon nutmeg with the flour. Substitute 1 cup semi-sweet chocolate pieces for the apricots.
There is no frozen chopped broccoli or fresh broccoli in China. The Chinese use a green vegetable quite similar to broccoli in this recipe, which the housewife has to parboil, cool and chop.
- 1 tablespoon pimiento, cut into small squares
- Liquid red-pepper seasoning to 1/2 teaspoon, according to taste
1. Thaw and drain broccoli. Make sure all the pieces are finely chopped. Mix with minced water chestnuts. In a bowl mix soy sauce, oil, sugar and red-pepper seasoning.
2. Five minutes before you are ready to serve, pour sauce over broccoli. Toss to blend ingredients. Sprinkle pimiento over the salad. At the table, mix again before serving.

MIX all ingredients until dough forms; beat 30 sec. If dough is too sticky, gradually stir in enough baking mix (up to 1/4 cup) to make dough easy to handle. **TURN** dough onto surface well dusted with baking mix; gently roll in baking mix to coat. Shape into ball; knead 10 times. Roll 1/2"
thick. Cut with 2" cutter dipped in baking mix. BAKE on greased cookie sheet until golden brown, 8 to 10 min. About 14 biscuits.
**Drop Cheese Biscuits: After** beating, drop dough by rounded spoonfuls onto greased cookie sheet. Bake until golden brown. 10 to 12 min. Carefully loosen from cookie sheet.
**High Altitude Directions (3500)** to 6500 ft.): Increase oven temperature to 475.

Bake in a 350°F. oven for about 1 hour or until wooden pick inserted in center comes out clean. Cool in pan 15 minutes. Turn out on wire rack to cool thoroughly. Drizzle glaze over cake. Cut in thin slices to serve. Makes 10 to 12 servings.

transcription: CHERRY SWIRL CAKE 1 pkg. Pillsbury Plus White Cake Mix 3 egg whites 1 cup water  $\frac{1}{3}$  cup oil 21-oz. can cherry fruit filling Whipped topping if desired Heat oven to 350°F. Generously grease and lightly flour 13x9-inch pan. In large mixer bowl, blend first four ingredients until moistened. Beat 2 minutes at highest speed. Pour into pan. Reserve 1 cup cherry fruit filling for topping. Spoon remaining cherry fruit filling over cake batter; gently swirl through batter to marble. Bake at 350°F. for 35 to 45 minutes or until toothpick inserted in center comes out clean. Cool. Spread reserved cherry fruit filling over cake. Top with whipped topping if desired. - 1 cup Quaker or Mother's Oats (quick or old fashioned, uncooked)

For cake, pour boiling water over oats; cover and let stand 20 minutes. Beat, butter until creamy; gradually add sugars and beat until fluffy. Blend in vanilla and eggs. Add oats mixture; mix well. Sift together flour, soda, salt, cinnamon and nutmeg. Add to creamed mixture. Mix well. Pour batter into well-greased and floured 9-inch square pan. Bake in preheated moderate oven (350°F.) for 50 to 55 minutes. Do not remove cake from pan. For frosting, combine all ingredients. Spread evenly over cake. Broil until frosting becomes bubbly. Cake may be served warm or cold.

Most regreables, from asparagus to mechini, can be dehydrated at home. Select garden fresh, top-quality produce for the best results. Remember, although dried regerables retain most of their vitamin and mineral content and good flavor, the original quality cannot be improved.

All vegetables require some preparation, such as removing stems, peelor seeds, before drying. Like fruits, uniformly cut slices or pieces result in even drying. Unlike fruits, regetables are better out slightly smaller to hasten drying time. Vegetables lose flavor and tenderness if the drying time is prolonged. Drying time varies from about 4 to 14 hours. A temperature of 125°F is recommended for most vegerables. Finished vegerables should contain about 5% moisture. When tested, regetables should look and feel crisp or brittle.
Vegetables can be eaten dried, but they are usually reconstituted

Crush or grind habañero peppers, scallions and whole allspice to a coarse powder. Add remaining ingredients and grind to a uniformly coarse powder. Store in home canning jar, plastic jar or plastic storage container. Label and date.

Drench meat in a sauce prepared with 1/3 cup red wine vinegar, 2 tablespoons canola oil and 1 tablespoon soy sauce. Apply rub. Let shrimp stand 2 to 4 hours; chicken, beef and lamb cubes 4 to 6 hours; pork 3 to 4 hours and ribs overnight in a cool place. Grill.
Note: When curring or seeding hot peppers, wear rubber gloves to prevent hands from being burned.

transcription: When garlic is roasted, it becomes mild and soft enough to spread over bread or crackers. For additional herb flavor, place a sprig of fresh thyme over the cut surface of the garlic before roasting. Roasted garlic can also be used to flavor cream of potato soup. Simply roast as directed. 4 whole garlic heads 1/3 cup water 1/4 cup olive or vegetable oil Sliced French or Italian bread

Cut the top off of each garlic head (the end that comes to a closed point) so that each clove is exposed. Place with cut side up in a small ungreased baking dish; pour water around garlic. Cover and bake at 350° for 1 hour or until garlic is very soft. Cool for 5 minutes. Slowly drizzle oil into the center and over each garlic head. Remove soft garlic from skins; spread on bread or over cooked meats or vegetables.
With a sharp knife, cut off the top of each head of garlic, exposing the cloves inside. Place in a small baking dish; bake as directed.

**EXCESSIVE FOAMING** may be minimized by adding 1/4 feaspoon buffer or margarine to jam or jelly during the fimed boiling period. Allow 30 seconds for foam to subside before starting to skim. (Flavor and texture are not affected; yield increases and jellies will be clearer.)

SLOW SETTING JAMS and JELLIES sometimes occurs (they may take up to 2 weeks). This is due to the type of fruit used, its degree of ripeness and fartness. Some examples are apricots, cherries and peaches.

TRY OUR OTHER PRODUCTS: Use SLIM SET® Fruit Pectin for making jams and jellies with less sugar or with sugar substitutes and use A-C-M<sup>®</sup> EVER-FRESHTM (ascorbic ocid mixture) to prevent browning and protect the flovor of light-colored fruits.
SPECIAL RECIPES are available. These include recipes using honey, unique fruits, dried fruit, bottled or frozen juices and recipes for syrups and bandies

transcription: ## Notés from Bonnie Yogurt: A Kitchen Staple
## For Great Dishes In Fast Style

Fast is better only if the results live up to expectations. With yogurt in your refrigerator, you can turn out interesting dishes in a matter of minutes which meet the criteria of delicious, lowfat, low cholesterol foods.

Think of yogurt as a staple in your kitchen to blend with many herbs, spices, condiments, sweeteners and convenience products for flavorful, pleasurable eating. The following formulas will give you some ideas.

$1/2$  cup yogurt  $+1$  tsp. cornstarch = thickener for cooked sauces 1 cup yogurt + 1 tsp. mustard = mayonnaise alternative (salt  $\&$ pepper to taste) 1 cup yogurt + 2 tbsp. all-purpose flour = cream base for hot soups  $1/2$  cup yogurt + 2 tbsp. ricotta cheese = base for dips 1 cup yogurt + 1 pkg. instant pudding mix = creamy dessert  $1$  cup yogurt + 2-3 tsp. fruit spread = dessert topping 1 cup yogurt + 1 cup sweetened rhubarb (layered) = refreshing dessert 1 cup yogurt +  $1/2$  cup chutney = dip for fresh fruit  $1/2$  cup yogurt  $+1$  tsp. prepared horseradish = topping for burgers, ham or chops

- 5 tbsp half and half or milk  $\bullet$
- Nuts over cake batter before meringue
- . Whipped cream sweetened with powdered sugar and vanilla or vanilla sugar
- 1. Turn oven on to 425 degrees but lower to 325 when cake is ready to put in.
- 2. Mix room temperature butter and sugar. Add the egg yolks one at a time while beating with mixer. Mix baking powder and flour and then add to egg mixture alternating with milk.
- 3. Beat the egg whites to the hardest foam possible. Mix baking powder and sugar together then carefully mix into the egg mixture.

- 4. Line a baking pan with parchment paper all of the way up the sides (I used a jell roll pan). Brush the paper with butter. Spread the cake batter over the entire surface. It will seem thin. If adding nuts spread them at this time. Cover the batter with the meringue mixture.
- 5. Bake about 25-35 minutes but take out to check that the cake is done under the meringue.
- 6. Let cake cool. Cut in half and put together with cream, berries etc.

transcription: ## **Best of the Best: BOSTON BAKED BEANS**

NEW ENGLANDERS say there's no finer eating than Boston Baked Beans, sweet with molasses and spiced with a hint of pork and savory onion. But-this may come as a surprise-the real Yankee version of this bean dish is never simmered stove-top! It's made with soaked beans, baked in the oven and moistened with warm water.

That's exactly the way it's done at Boston's famous Durgin-Park Restaurant, founded in 1742 and known by its motto: "Good food on the table and plenteous portions." Here, there's a special cook just for the beans. He's the 1. Soak beans overnight in a large bow in the 6 cups water. Place beans with soaking water in a large lettle ald baking soda; bring to boiling fower heat and continue to boil for 10 minutes. Drain in colander over large bowl. reserving liquid.

2. Place salt pork, onion and reans in a 2-quart bean pot or casserole. Combine molasses, sugar, dry mustard, pepper and 1 cup of the reserved liquid. Pour over beans, stir thoroughly. Add just enough reserved liquid to cover bears (about I cup). Cover casserois. 3. Bake in a slow oven (300°) for 2 hours. Add remaining 1 cup liquid and stir thoroughly. Continue baking an additional 11/2 to 2 hours or until beans are tender and liquid is alsorbed. Bake

Warm the milk to body temperature (98 degrees). Pour it over the yeast in a bowl. Stir until the yeast is dissolved. Add 1/3 cup of the white syrup and a little less than 4 cups of the flour. Beat it in a mixer until it is smooth and a rather loose dough. Cover it with a towel and let it rise for at least 30 minutes. It will double in size.

Dot the butter into the batter and mix it. Beat the egg and add the rest of the syrup, the egg and the salt and the cardamom. Finally add the rest of the flour. Beat it all together into a smooth dough.
Turn dough onto floured board. Divide the dough into 30 pieces and roll each one into a ball.
Cover two cookie sheets with baking paper and put the balls on the sheets, fifteen on each. Let them rise for 45 - 60 minutes.

## LIQUEUR: Make your own brightly colored treats as gifts for
any food gift. It is both a courtesy and a safety measure, since any food or ingestible may hold some risk for triggering an allergic reaction.

To make a homemade liqueur gift more special, include a set of cordial glasses. They will be a subtie reminder that liqueurs should be consumed in small amounts. A few sins (about 1 ounce) in a miniature gobiet is an appropriate serving for these sweet drinks
You might also include a food gift, and recipe that use the liqueur. As an example, we've adapted a simple pound cake recipe for holiday gift-giving.
Who knows, if your homemade gifts are a hit this season, you may want to plan for next year and take advantage of summer's bounty to brew up some blueberry, peach or raspberry liqueurs.

transcription: NEIMAN MARCUS \$250.00 COOKIE RECIFE A friend of a friend had lunch at the Hedges at Neiman Marcus in November, and for dessert she had a cookie. She thought it was the most wonderful cookie she had ever tasted and asked if the recipe was available. She was told that it was but there was a charge of two-fifty. She said that was fine, got the recipe and told them to just charge her account.

In December when she got her bill, there was a charge of \$250.00. She called and told them there was a mistake. that the charge should be \$2.50. She was told there was NO mistake--that the charge was correct. They told her it was not a returnable item and she would have to pay the amount charged to her account of become delinquent in her payments.

The bottom line is, she paid. She has vowed to get them back, and wants to get the recipe out to everyone she possibly can, and asks that everyone who gets a copy send it to everyone they know. It's amazingly simple to make-just three ingredients. and less than a half hour required—and it's more delicate than store-bought fresh ricotta. Plus, it's only half the price! Use this rich, fluffy cheese for lasagna, cannoli, or simple crostini (with a drizzle of extra virgin olive oil or topped) with chopped fresh herbs). Dieters: See the reduced-fat version, below.
Active time 5 minutes Total time 25 minutes plus standing Makes 15 ounces or about 2 cups
1. Line large strainer with 4 layers cheesecloth and place lined strainer in large bowl; set aside.
2. In heavy-bottom 4-quart saucepan, heat milk and I teaspoon salt to boiling on medium-high, stirring occasionally to prevent milk from scorching.

3. Stir in lemon juice; cover and remove from heat. Let stand 5 minutes. With slotted spoon, gently transfer curds from saucepan to lined strainer. Drain 3 minutes. Discard whey in bowl. 4. If not using right away, transfer ricotta to clean bowl, cover, and refrigerate up to 1 week.
**EACH TABLESPOON** About 25 calories, 2 g protein, 0 g carbohydrate, 2 g total fat (1 g saturated), 0 g fiber, 8 mg cholesterol, 30 mg sodium.
Reduced-Fat Ricotta Substitute 4 cups reduced-fat (2%) milk for 4 cups whole milk, and follow recipe as above. Makes 15 ounces or about 2 cups.
**EACH TABLESPOON** About 25 calories, 2 g protein, 0 g carbohydrate, 1.5 g total fat (1 g saturated), 0 g fiber, 6 mg cholesterol, 30 mg sodium.

Jerky is raw meat or fish which is salted or marinated and dried. Although most any type of lean meat (beef, lamb, pork or game) or fish may be used, beef jerky is the easiest to make with the most reliable results. Choose any lean cut of beef. Flank, round or sirloin tip are excellent choices. Rump, if it is lean, is also a good choice. Use only a commercial or homemade electric food dehydrator. Do not attempt to dry meat in the sun due to risk of spoilage and contamination.
Freeze meat slightly to aid in slicing. Cut beef in strips, 1/2-inch thick, across the grain for a tender, slightly brittle finished product. Cut with the grain for a chewy end product.

The meat must be "cured"; that is, treated in such a way to prevent spoilage. Dry cures are salt and seasonings rubbed on the meat surface. Brine cures are marinades or liquid seasoning mixtures in which the meat is soaked for a period of time. Vacuum packaging sliced meat and marinade will reduce the length of time it takes for the marinade to penetrate the meat. Not only is this method quicker, but it allows the narinade to penetrate deeper, locking in the great taste. Dry meat in an electric dehydrator at 145°F. If fat droplets appear having the drying process, blot meat with a paper towel. To test a slice of near, allow to cool. It should bend but not break. Jerky must be brought to an internal temperature of 160°F just prior as deging as immediately after drying. Two methods are recommended: sear mane errige in merinade before drying by boiling 5 minutes. Or, heat ketspitcated meat arrips to an over at 77% for 10 minutes after the drying

Dry rubs are used for the intense complement of flavors they impart, and the crusty coating they wrap around a wide variety of meat, poultry, seafood and game. Rubs made fresh surpass the spice blends or seasoning packets available in stores. They are easy to make even if you do not grow all the ingredients in your back yard. However, you can take full advantage of fresh herbs and other edibles you do grow. When purchasing ingredients to fill-in where you do not have your own supply, select whole spices and herbs, grinding them as needed.

Preparing dry rubs takes no more than a few minutes. Ingredients can be crushed with a mortar and pestle, ground in a hand-held grinder or pulsed in a food processor. Be careful when using a food processor that the mixture does not break down too fat, causing natural oils to release. If this happens the rub will need to be used quickly because the oils will turn rancid.

- 3 lemons, cut into wedges, seeds removed
1. Season chicken with salt and pepper. In a large nonstick skillet, heat 1 Tbsp oil over medium. Cook chicken 3 to 4 minutes per side, until cooked through and slightly browned. Remove from skillet.

transcription: Appetizers whet the appetite and hint at the meal to follow. A good beginning to the meal, there should not be too many nor too much. A few appetizers are more appealing than an overwhelming wariety. If foods are to be eaten, serve with beverages for more enjoyment. Includes hors d'oeurves, beverages, or savory food served before a meal.
Appetizers to be eaten as finger foods should be bite-size. If other than fresh vegetables, they should be eaten from a wooden or plastic pick.
Choose complementary flavors for the rest of the meal to keep appetizers tantalizing. Use texture contrasts, color contrasts and a variety of shapes.
To prevent a last-minute rush, prepare some or all before the event.

## No Sugar Needed Cooked Jam Directions using Splenda®
(Traditional cooked method, slightly softer set, nice tart cooked fruit taste.)
1 Place prepared fruit in large saucepan. Stir in 3/4 cup water\* and 1 pkg. SURE-JELL For Less or No Sugar Needed Recipes Premium Fruit Pectin. \*\*

2 Bring mixture to full rolling boil (a boil that doesn't stop bubbling when stirred) on high heat, stirring constantly. Boil exactly 1 min., stirring constantly. Remove from heat. Stir in SPLENDA® Granulated or SPLENDA® Packets. Skim off any foam with metal spoon.
3 Ladle immediately into prepared jars, filling each to within 1/4 inch of top. Proceed as directed in Cooked Jam Directions (Steps 6 & 7).

\*Note: For a sweeter jam with a firmer set, prepare as directed substituting 1 thawed can (12 oz.) frozen white grape juice concentrate or 1 thawed can (12 oz.) frozen apple juice concentrate for the 3/4 cup water. Makes about 4 cups. **\*\*For complete recipe details see chart.**

transcription: Personally. I hate to make salads. Whenever people ask what they can bring to dinner, I blurt out "salad" without a moment's hesitation. Maybe that's because I'm not so good at making them. My friend Sandi, on the other hand, makes a faller salad. Here are her rules:
- 1. Use a good homemade salad dressing (see recipes).
- 2. Dress the salad in moderation-don't drown the greens.
- 3. Use greens that actually have some. flavor-arugula, spring mix, frisée, spinach, radicchio, máche, watercress and endive.
- 4. Consider contrasts in your saladsweet dried cranberries or raisins with sharp feta cheese, rich walnuts with bright crisp radishes or carrots.
- 5. Actually toss the salad. This way all the ingredients get coated with the dressing. (There's a reason it's called a "tossed" salad.) -Jill Melton

Cooking up a little extra on weekends can be the key to made-in-minutes meals during the rest of the week.
LEFTOVERS can make a quick and easy meal during the middle of the week-without looking or tasting the same the second (or even third) time around!
Each issue, we will feature hearty weekend-meal menus that include "planned" leftovers-along with speedy weekday recipes to use them up.
This time, you can start by treating your family to Favorite Pot Roast or Turkey Breast with Gravy (see the recipes on these pages).
Later, you can surprise them with a whole different meal or two using the leftovers (also included here).

One of the easiest candias to make, and one that deserves its popularity.

1. Combine sugar, corn syrup, water, salt and butter in a large saucepan. Cook, stirring constantly, until sugar dissolves. Cover pan for 1 minute to allow the steam to wash down the sugar crystals that cling to side of pan, or wipe down the crystals with a damp cloth. 2. Uncover pan; insert candy thermometer. Cook without stirring until candy thermometer reaches 270° (soft crack stage, where syrup, when dropped into very cold water, separates into hard but not brittle threads). **3.** Remove from heat; stir in almonds; return to heat. Continue cooking until candy thermometer reaches 300° (hard crack stage, where syrup, when dropped into very cold water, separates into threads that are hard and brittle). 4. ## What to Do if Your Freezer Jam or Jelly Doesn't Set
1 Prepare Containers: Rinse clean plastic containers and lids with boiling water; dry thoroughly.

2 Prepare Pectin Mixture: Gradually add 1 pkg. SURE-JELL For Less or No Sugar Needed Recipes Premium Fruit Pectin to 1-1/2 cups water in small saucepan. stirring constantly. Bring to boil on medium heat; boil 2 min., stirring constantly. Remove from heat.

3 Trial Batch: Measure 1 cup unset jam or jelly into small bowl. Add 2 Tbsp. sugar; stir 3 min. or until completely dissolved. Add 1 Tbsp. of the pectin mixture; stir an additional 3 min. Immediately pour into one of the prepared containers. Cover and let stand up to 24 hours before checking to see if set. Meanwhile, store remaining pectin mixture in refrigerator. 4 Remainder of Batch: If Trial Batch sets satisfactorily, prepare remaining jam or jelly, remaking no more than 8 cups of jam or jelly at one time and using same directions as for Trial Batch with the above-listed measures of sugar and pectin mixture for each 1 cup of jam or jelly. Pour into prepared containers. Discard any leftover pectin mixture.
## What to Do if Your Cooked Jam or Jelly Doesn't Set
1 Prepare Jars as directed in Cooked Jam directions on other side.

2 Prepare Pectin Mixture: Slowly stir contents of 1 pkg. SURE-JELL For Less or No Sugar Needed Recipes Premium Fruit Pectin into 1-1/2 cups cold water in small saucepan. Bring to boil on medium heat; boil 2 min., stirring constantly. Remove from heat.

3 Trial Batch: Measure 1 cup unset jam or jelly, 2 Tbsp. sugar and 1 Tbsp. Pectin Mixture (from step 2) into small saucepan. Bring mixture to full rolling boil (a boil that doesn't stop bubbling when stirred) on high heat, stirring constantly. Boil 30 sec., stirring constantly. Remove from heat. Skim off any foam. Pour jam or jelly into prepared jar; cover. Let stand 24 hours before checking set. Refrigerate remaining pectin mixture.

4 Remainder of Batch: Do not remake more than 8 cups of jam or jelly at one time. If Trial Batch sets follow the recipe above, using listed measures of sugar and Pectin Mixture for each 1 cup of jam or jelly. Measure jam or jelly into stockpot. Bring to full rolling boil; boil 30 sec., stirring constantly. Remove from heat. Skim off any foam with metal spoon. Ladle jam or jelly into prepared jars. Follow boiling water bath method to process jars. Discard any leftover pectin mixture.

- 1. Bring boiling-water canner, half-full with water, to simmer.

- 2. Wash jars and screw bands in hot, soapy water; rinse with warm water. Pour boiling water over flat lids in saucepan off the heat. Let stand in hot water until ready to use. Drain well before filling.

- 3. Prepare fruit as directed in following charts. For berries, crush 1 cup at a time, using a potato masher for best results. If using food processor, pulse to chop. DO NOT PUREE. Jam should have bits of fruit.
- 4. Measure exact amount of prepared fruit (or juice for jelly) into 6- or 8-quart saucepot. Stir in lemon juice and water (if required) as indicated in chart.

- 5. Measure exact amount of sugar into separate bowl. (REDUCING SUGAR OR USING SUGAR SUBSTITUTES WILL RESULT IN SET FAILURES.) Try Sure-Jell for Less or No Sugar Needed Recipes Fruit Pectin for no- or low-sugar jams and jellies.
- 6. Stir 1 box pectin into fruit or juice in saucepot. Add 1/2 teaspoon butter or margarine to reduce foaming, if desired.
- 7. Bring mixture to full rolling boil (a boil that doesn't stop bubbling when stirred) on high heat, stirring constantly.
- 8. Stir in sugar quickly. Return to full rolling boil and boil exactly 4 minutes for JAMS and 2 minutes for JELLIES, stirring constantly. Remove from heat. Skim off any foam with metal spoon.

- 9. Ladle quickly into prepared jars, filling to within 1/8 inch of tops. Wipe jar rims and threads. Cover with two-piece lids. Screw bands tightly (see Note on reverse side)\*. Place jars on elevated rack in canner. Lower rack into canner. Water must cover jars by 1 to 2 inches; add boiling water if needed. Cover; bring water to gentle boil. Process jams 10 minutes; jelly 5 minutes. Adjust processing time according to Altitude Chart (on reverse side). Remove jars and place upright on a towel to cool completely. After jars cool, check seals by pressing middle of

lid with finger. (If lid springs back, lid is not sealed and refrigeration is necessary.) 10. Let stand at room temperature 24 hours (or time indicated on recipe). Store unopened jams and jellies in cool, dry, dark place up to 1 year, Refrigerate opened jams and jellies up to 3 weeks. **CONTRACTOR DE REALITA**

transcription: #### Peach-Amaretto Freezer Jam (Yield: Seven S-oz. jars)
Wash. Peel, pit, slice and finely grind peaches.
- 1. Measure prepared pulp and lemon juice into large saucepan. If short of fruit pulp, add water
- 2. Slowly stir in 1 package of MCP Poctin and mix thoroughly. Set aside for 30 minutes, stirring every 5 minutes to dissolve pectin completely.
- 3. Add light Karo corn syrup and mix well. This prevents sugar crystallization during freezer storage.
- 4. Add premeasured sugar gradually. Stir well to dissolve completely. Warming to 100°F (haby hortle temperature) will hasten dissolving. No hotter, please.
- 5. After sugar is thoroughly dissolved, stir in Amaretto, pour into containers and seal.
- 6. Store freezer jam in freezer. Refrigerate after opening.
Peaches: Wash. Peel, pit, slice and finely grind. Strawberries: Wash, stem and crush or grind finely.
- 1. Measure prepared pulp and lemon juice into large saucepan. If short of fruit pulp, add water.
- 2. Slowly stir in 1 package of MCP Pectin and mix thoroughly. Set aside for 30 minutes, stirring every 5 minutes to dissolve pectin completely.
- 3. Add light Karo corn syrup and mix well. This prevents sugar crystallization during freezer
- 4. Add premeasured sugar gradually. Stir well to dissolve completely. Warming to 100°F (baby bottle temperature) will hasten dissolving. No hotter, please.
- 5. After sugar is thoroughly dissolved, stir in Amaretto, pour into containers and seal.
- 6. Store freezer jam in freezer. Refrigerate after opening.

~1/2 lb. pork cubes trimmed of fat (trimmed weight), about 3 1/2 cups. ~1 packet taco seasoningmix ~1 (10 oz.) can enchilada sauce ~1 (4oz) can diced green chiles ~1 medium onion, peeled and chopped. ~3 cups mesa flour ~1/3 cup shortening ~2 1/2 cups chicken broth ~1 1/2 tsp, each salt and baking powder ~ dried corn husks, soaked in hot water overnight Salsa, sour cream and quacamole.

In a medium saucepan combine pork with taco seasoning mix, enchilada sauce, chiles and onion. Cover and simmer for 11/2 hours. Remove cover and cook over medium high heat for about 20 minutes or until most of the liquid has been absorbed. Let it cool slighlty and shred, using two forks. Meanwhile, to prepare tamale dough, place masa flour and shortening in a large bowl; cut in shortening. Using a mixer, beat in broth until mixture is about the constistency of thick cake batter. (Add a little more broth if mixture is too thick.) Using the largest of the cornhusks, spread about 1/4 cup of the masa dough in a square in the center of the husk. Place a few tablespoons of the shredded pork filling in the center of the masa. Roll up the cornhusks so that the masa meets to enclose filling. Tear 1/4-inch strips from extra cornhusks and tie each end of the tamale tightly. Repeat with remaining masa and filling. Place a rack or steamer basket in a very large stockpot (or use 2 pots). Stand tamales up in the pot, being careful not to overcrowd. (Place additional cornhusks between tamales to get them to stand up.) Place water in the pot until it is just below tamales. Cover and steam for about 1 hour or until masa dough is firm. Serve with salsa, sour cream and guacamole.

transcription: Dry rubs store on the shelf for 1 to 3 assurabs, depending on the blend of ingredients. Not all ingredients will age at the same rate, so the flavor of the rub may change the longer it is moved. This is one reason why it is bear to prepare small amounts and use them quickly. Rubs are sensitive to light and heat. Keep dry rubs in a home canning jar or plastic murage container and place in a cabinet to protect the rub from light and hear.

The reasoning or flavoring characteristics of a dry rub is givar. Only a small amount. I tablespoon or less, is needed to season a single fish filler, chicken breast or steak. Larger cuts of meat or whole portions of poultry and fish use about 16 cup. Depending on how the dry rub is to be used, there may be some remaining for a second use. To prevent the contamination of remaining rub during initial use, measure only the amount of rub needed for one application in a separate dish.
Rubs are often prepared using fresh ingredients. But many of the same ingredients can be used in their dry state. The time required to airdry fresh ingredients can be minimized using a dehydrator.
- 11/2 teaspoons ground cinnamon 1 teaspoon ground coriander

Apply rub, using 1 rablespoon for chicken breast and 4 rable. spoons for 1 pound of shrimp or limb cubes. Let shrimp stand 2 m 4 hours; chicken and lamb cubes 4 or 6 hours in a cool place. Grill.

Most vegetables, from asparagus to mechini, can be dehydrated at home. Select garden fresh, top quality produce for the best results. Remember, although dried regetables retain most of their vitamin and mineral content and good flavor, the original quality cannot be improved.

All vegetables require some preparation, such as removing stems, peel. or seeds, before drying. Like fruits, uniformly cut slices or pieces result in even drying. Unlike fruits, regerables are better out slightly smaller to hasten drying time. Vegetables lose flavor and tenderness if the drying time is prolonged. Drying time varies from about 4 to 14 hours. A temperature of 125°F is recommended for most vegetables. Finished vegetables should contain about 5% moisture. When tested, vegetables should, look and feel crisp or brittle.

Crush or grind habañero peppers, scallions and whole allspice to a coarse powder. Add remaining ingredients and grind to a uniformly coarse powder. Store in home canning jar, plastic jar or plastic storage container. Label and date.

Recommended Use: Shrimp, chicken breast, pork chops, spareribs and beef or lamb kabobs. Drench meat in a sauce prepared with 1/3 cup red wine vinegar, 2 tablespoons canola oil and 1 tablespoon soy sauce. Apply rub. Let shrimp stand 2 to 4 hours; chicken, beef and lamb cubes 4 to 6 hours; pork 3 to 4 hours and ribs overnight in a cool place. Grill.
Note: When cutting or seeding hot peppers, wear rubber gloves to prevent hands from being burned.
- 1 cup dried parsley V<sub>2</sub> cup dried oregano **We cup dried rosemary**
just or phaseic morage corespiracy. Labod and date:
Crush or grind herbs to a coarse powder. Stir in salt and pepper. Store in home canning jar or plastic storage container. Label and date.
Recommended Use: Chicken and fish. Coat meat lightly with olive oil. Apply rub. Let chicken and fish stand 2 to 4 hours in a cool place. Grill.
Vegetables can be eaten dried, but they are usually reconstituted before using. An equal volume of water and vegetables is needed. Boiling water will shorten the rehydration time.
Generally, it takes 15 minutes to 3 hours for reconstituting vegetables. depending on the texture and thickness of the vegetables.
If a vegetable is not listed in the following pages, freezing or canning may be a more suitable method of food preservation.

4 tablespoons unsalted butter 2 medium yellow onions, peeled and sliced 1/2 teaspoon garlic powder 1/4 teaspoon salt freshly ground black pepper to taste 1 flank steak, about 11/4-11/2 pounds 1/2 cup beef broth 2 teaspoons Lea & Perrins Worcestershire Sauce 2 teaspoons tomato paste

1. Heat 2 tablespoons butter in a large heavy skillet. Add onion, garlic powder. salt and pepper. Cook over medium-low heat until the onions are wilted and slightly golden, about 15 minutes. Remove the onions with a slotted spoon and set aside.
2. Add remaining butter to the skillet. Increase heat to medium. Season the steak with salt and pepper and saute it until browned on the outside and pink and juicy on the inside, 3-5 minutes per
side depending on thickness. Transfer to a cutting board and keep warm.
3. Pour off the fat, and return the onions to the skillet. Stir in remaining ingredients and cook until heated through and slightly thickened about 2-3 minutes.
4. Quickly slice the steak across the grain and at an angle into thin strips. Spoon the heated sauce over the steak and serve.

Spicy sausage and peppers fill a crispy

4 Italian hard rolls 1 pound sweet or hot sausages or a combination of both 1 large onion, chopped (1 cup) 2 medium-size green peppers, halved, seeded and cut into thin strips 1 can (8 ounces) tomato sauce  $\boldsymbol{\mu}$

1. Cut rolls in half lengthwise; scoop out center of each bottom half to make a boat-shaped shell. Tear scooped-out bread into small pieces with your fingers, or place a little at a time into electric blender container; cover; whirl at high speed 15 seconds. Measure out 1/2 cup; reserve. (Save remainder to use as a crumb topping for a casserole.)
2. Remove sausage from casings; break into small pieces. Cook slowly in a large skillet about 15 minutes or until browned.

3. Add onions and green pepper to skillet; sauté 5 minutes or until softened. Drain off excess fat. Stir in tomato sauce. Cook over moderate heat until mixture thickens, about 10 minutes. Stir in the 1/2 cup reserved bread crumbs.
4. Place rolls on cookie sheet. Broil 5 minutes or until lightly toasted.
5. Spoon sausage mixture into rolls. Cover with tops. Secure with wooden picks; cut sandwiches in half. Serve hot with knife and fork.
1 cup butter or margarine 1 cup sugar 2 tablespoons water I tablespoon light corn syrup 1 cup chopped walnuts 1/2 cup semisweet chocolate pieces

Melt butter in large heavy saucepan over low heat. Stir in sugar, water and syrup and bring to boil over medium heat, stirring constantly. Turn heat to low and simmer without stirring until candy thermometer reaches 290°. Remove from heat and stir in walnuts. Spread in greased 13x9x2inch pan. Sprinkle with chocolate pieces and let stand a few minutes until melted; spread chocolate evenly over top. Cool in pan on rack until firm and chocolate is set. Break in pieces; store airtight in single layers between sheets of waxed paper in cool dry place. Makes about 1-1/4 pounds.

Rosarita®Traditional Refried Beans offer the delicious taste you've come to expect and are 98% fat free. Quality beans are prepared with only natural ingredients and a unique blend of savory seasonings. High in fiber and a good source of protein, our Refried Beans are a versatile and welcome side dish. **Heating Instructions: Empty contents into saucepan** and cook over medium heat until hot and bubbly. Stir occasionally.
For easy clean-up, spray pan with Wesson® No-Stick **Cooking Spray before heating.**
Microwave Directions: Empty into microwave-safe glass baking dish. Cover with plastic wrap. Heat for 4 minutes on high, turning dish and stirring once halfway through cooking time.

(CF) In heavy 2-quart saucepan heat water, butter, sugar and salt until butter melts; bring to boil. Remove from heat and add flour all at once. Beat with wooden spoon until thoroughly blended. transcription: Zucchini Oven Fries Cut 2 (12 oz) zucchini into 3-inch sticks. In a bowl mix together 1/2 cup panko bread crumbs, 1/4 cup shredded Parmesan, 1/8 tsp ground cumin, 1/2 tsp garlic powder, 1 tsp dried oregano, 1/4 tsp paprika and 1 tsp kosher salt. Add 2 tsp olive oil and mix with fingertips until combined. In a separate bowl beat 2 egg whites until

frothy. Toss zucchini sticks in the egg whites. Working in batches, transfer sticks to the bread crumb mixture, press crumbs onto zucchini and place on a baking sheet. Bake at 450°F until golden and just tender, about 12 min. Serve immediately. **SERVES 4 TO 6**

transcription: ## PASS A PIECE-A PASTA PIE

Cousin Ginny, Aunt Patsy's daughter knows "no offer!" But to her this word. "pasta," means either something afready happened, past tense, or someone better "pasta" the food real quick before Cousin David eats it all!

I onion chopped I lb ground turkey (or hamburger). 1-141/2 or stewed tomatoes, undrained 1-15 oz can tomato sauce I teaspoon thyme leaves I teaspoon basil leaves 16 teaspoon ground cumin 14 teaspoon salt dash pepper 1-11 oz can corn, drained 1-15 oz can black beans (or kidneys) 1-6 oz can small black pitted olives, drained I cup chopped green pepper 12 oz spaghetti noodles (no, Aunt Patsy doesn't have any so you'll have to use brand X!) 3 cups (12 oz) grated cheddar cheese
The only thing stacked about Aunt Patsy is her macaroni? This is a "dinner version" of an ice cream sundae with toppenes.

I lb lean ground beef or turkey I cup chopped onion 1-15 or can tomato sauce L-R or can formato tauce I teaspoon dried oregano leaves I teaspoon dried basil leaves I teaspoon dried thyme leaves 14 teaspoon salt 14 teaspoon pepper 12 or Aunt Patsy's pasta, cooked, or 4 cups cooked rice 1-10 oz package frozen peas (2 cups) 8 oz cheddar cheese, grated

In a skillet, brown the meat with onion, drain off fat. Add tomato sauces, oregano, basil, thyme, salt and pepper. Simmer, stirring occasionally for 30 minutes. Meanwhile cook the pasta or rice according to instructions. Cook peas. On individual plates . . . start stacking! First mac (or rice) then the meat mixture then peas then cheese. Need a "cherry" on top? Try a chili pepper.

Cousin David used to bring home a friend called "Strop." He used to like this chicken dish so much and would help. himself to so many servings that Aunt. Patsy was always yelling ... "Stron! Fnough! Enough!"

> I small onion, chopped. 2 Ib boneless, skinless chicken breasts. cut in small cubes 2 tablespoons oil 1/3 cup butter (the real stuff!) 2/3 cup flour I teaspoon thyme dash nutmeg I cup chicken broth I cup milk 1/2 cup white wine 1/2 teaspoon salt % cup grated parmesan cheese 4 oz can mushrooms, drained, (or 1/4 lb fresh mushrooms, sliced and sauted) 8 oz sour cream (very optional - this is pretty creamy already) 12 oz of your favorite Aunt Patsy Pasta cooked according to instructions

Brown onion and turkey in large skillet. Drain any grease. Add stewed tomatoes, tomato sauce, thyme, basil, cumin, salt, and pepper. Now just let this stuff simmer for 15-20 minutes, till thicker. Dump in the drained corn, beans, olives, and green pepper. If your skillet wasn't large enough, you'll have to dump this all in a large bowl so you can mix it without decorating the counter with it! Don't squash the olives when you mix (Cousin David can't get squashed olives to stay on his fingers).

Cook the spaghetti according the directions and drain. Lightly grease two 10" pie plates and arrange the spaghetti as a crust. Cousin Ginny doesn't have 10" pie plates, so she uses 8" square pans. She says instead of pasta pies she now has a square meal!
Divide the stuff from the large bowl (unless you were one of the smart large skillet people) into the 2 "pie crusts." Sprinkle the cheese on top of both. Bake at 375° for 40 minutes. Cut and serve.

Yes, this does make alot of pie. At Aunt Patsy's house, Cousin David eats one and the whole rest of the family splits the other one. Or cut the recipe in half. Cousin Ginny freezes one for later (we think you can freeze this anyway . . .).
Aunt Patsy would prefer a recipe for Apple Jack but we told her this was a family recipe edition.
> 2 cups cubed red apples 2 cups (dry) pasta-cooked I cup chopped celery 1/2 cup walnut pieces (or almonds) cup good quality mayonnaise 2 tablespoons lemon juice I teaspoon sugar

Mix all of the ingredients except the pasta together in a large bowl. Put the bowl in the fridge to chill. Just before serving time, cook the pasta according to directions. Rinse with cold water until cool. Drain. Add the cooked pasta to the other ingredients. Gently stir together and serve.
Quickly stir-fry the chicken and onions in a pan with the 2 tablespoons oil till the chicken is done, about 10 minutes. Remove to dish and keep warm.

Melt the 1/3 cup butter in the pan, add the flour and blend in. Dump in the thyme, salt, and dash of nutmeg. Gradually add the chicken broth, milk, and wine (sometimes we catch Aunt Patsy adding the wine to herself not the recipe!) Continue to cook and stir till the sauce boils and thickens. Now dump in the parmesan cheese and cook just a little more. Add the chicken, onions, and mushrooms and heat thoroughly. If you like the way it tastes right now, stop, you're done. But if you want it even creamier, and can handle more fat, er, richness, throw in the sour cream. Lather the sauce over a plate of noodles and serve.

The noodles and sauce concoction can also be thrown all together in a casserole dish and baked for 30 minutes, too. This was Strog's favorite version cause then he could help himself to several large spoonfuls. Strog! Enough! Enough!

Brown sausage in a skillet over medium heat. Drain fat and transfer to Crock-Pot. Combine remaining Ingredients in Crock-Pot. Cover and cook on low 8 hours or high 4 hours. Remove bay leaves. Serve over cooked rice, Serves 6-8

For Valentine's Day, Mother's Day or the day you can't resist a sweet treat, Kahlua Cream Praline Brownies were created to both capture and warm the hearts of brownie lovers!
They get their taste-tempting "layered look" from a rich, moist combination of praline crust, kahlua and deep chocolate brownie center, kahlua buttercream frosting and chocolate glaze topping.

Prepare Praline Crust. Melt Chocolate with shortening over very low heat. Beat eggs with sugars and vanilla until blended. Stir in cooled chocolate mixture, then Kahlua. Add flour and salt, mixing to smooth batter. Stir in pecans. Turn into prepared pan. Bake in 350 deg. F oven, about 25 minutes, until pick inserted in center comes out clean (be careful not to overbake). Cool. Spread Kahlua Butter Cream Frosting over top and place in refrigerator a half hour to set. Spread Chocolate Glaze evenly over frosting and cool until set. Cut into small squares about 11/4 inches. Makes 3 dozen.
And Kahlua Cream Praline Brownies look as good as they taste, making them a nice choice for bridal showers or buffets where special treats which do not require utensils are so convenient and welcome.

transcription: Eggs are one of your best food buys. And they're so versatile and easy to prepare! For example, a dozen eggs (that's a pound and half of high-quality protein) can feed a family of 6 for less than a dollar. When eggs sell for 75¢ a dozen they're costing you only  $50<sup>4</sup>$  a pound!

And with those dozen eggs you can scramble up a super supper, fry some fantastic egg sandwiches, stir up an easy but elegant quiche or turn out a hearty casserole. Here are some super-fast egg ideas to help feed your family without busting your budget.

Instant Egg Pick-Up: blend an egg, a cup of orange juice and a teaspoon of honey in a blender or shaker jar. Makes a quick and easy breakfast or a super snack. Great for kids, on-the-go moms and dads, anybody.
Egg Taco: Scramble some eggs and spoon into crisp taco shells. Drizzle on taco or hot sauce, then sprinkle with cheese, lettuce, chopped tomato, whatever. Fast to fix, fun to eat, and cheap!
Kangaroo: Halve a piece of pocket bread and open each half to form a pouch. Then scramble eggs with some chopped ripe olives,

transcription: Lasking like roughhewn jewels, Westerncours nots are framed by these grandscule curamel cookies. Thin, crisp, and shiny they make striking desserts or impressive gifts.
Fragile to bite, the cookies are much easier to make and sturdier to handle than they look. The process is simple-but it requires some careful attention.
As the caramel around the nuts bakes, it spreads into a very thin layer 5 to 6 inches in diameter. You can bake only a few cosises at a time.

while hot, the caramel is soft. As it cools, the cookies become rigid. The trick is to get them off the pan after they harden enough not to stretch and tear, but before they get so brittle they break.
Stored airtight, these cookies stay crisp. If you want to make them more than a week ahead, they should be frozen for best flavor. W you're giving them away, handcarry them-very carefully.

In a 1- to 2-quart pan, melt butter over low heat. Add corn syrup and brown sugar. Stir over high heat until boiling. Remove pan from heat and blend in flour

Grease and flour 12- by 15-inch or 14- by 17-inch baking sheets (they must be flat, not warped). For each cooky, place 2 tablespoons of the nut mixture about 8 inches apart on the sheet-put only 2 cookies on a pan at a time.

With your fingers, push nuts apart into a 3- to 4-inch circle or oval. Bake in a 350° oven until cookies are a rich golden brown, about 10 minutes (if you have 2 pans in the oven, alternate positions at midpoint to ensure even browning).

Remove cookies from oven and let them cool on the pan until they firm up slightly, about 2 minutes; to test, slide a spatula under a corner. If the cooky is stretchy, wait just a few seconds longer. If it is hard, slide spatula under carefully and lift onto a rack. If cookies get too hard and stick to pan, return to oven to soften

When cool, serve, or immediately package airtight in rigid container. Cookies absorb moisture and lose their crispness quickly. If you stack the cookies in the containers, separate each layer with a sheet of waxed paper to protect them from breaking and sticking together. Hold at room temperature up to I week or freeze up to I month.

Low Fat Tomato Basil Soup Faona Haynes

As for the bottles used to make and package these gifts, here's your chance to recycle in style. Ordinary wide-mouth glass jars (juice bottles work well) are recommended for steeping.

For the final bottling, look for unusual, attractive glassware, new or used. My own assortment is largely saved from specialty vinegars and oils, augmented by occasional thriftshop finds. Add a few spent, behind-the-bar bottles and you may never need to buy fancy new bottles, which cost about \$10 to \$15 each.

All bottles should be washed to soak off old labels and obliterate old flavors and aromas. On the day they will be filled, sterilize the bottles in boiling water for 10 minutes, drain, dry, and let cool to room temperature before adding liqueurs.
If the bottles have no caps, shop for good-quality corks or stoppers at kitchen- or wine-supply shops. The last thing you want is to have liqueur leak out of a gift bottle laid on its side.

transcription: Cakes may be divided into two classes-Butter and Butterless or Sponge. A good Butter cake should be fine grained or of smooth texture. This is obtained by accurate measuring and skill in combining ingredients which require effort and time. The butter should be creamed until light colored. Fine granulated sugar should then be blended well with it. Eggs should be separated and well beaten before adding.

Dry ingredients should be sifted before and after measuring and these should be added alternately with the milk to the butter, sugar, and egg mixtures. Beaten egg whites and flavoring should be then folded into batter. Butter cakes require a moderate oven-350 to 400 degrees Fahrenheit. Sponge cakes require a slow oven-275 to 350 degrees Fahrenheit. Sponge cakes contain little liquid but great amounts of egg. Angel cake is a type of Sponge cake. Do not grease pans for sponge cakes. Frost cakes after they are cold.
Frosting should be cold when put on.

Skill is required in making good pastry. Flakiness, crispness and tenderness are characteristics of good pastry; and these are realized by the selection of good ingredients, accurate measurements and skillful mixing.
Pastry should not be made in a warm temperature.
Shortening should be worked in with a blender.
Ice water is conducive to tender pastry,

I am convinced that many of the really great dishes of this world have resulted from cooks' putting together the foods that just happened to be on hand. Consider beans with chill peppers; comed beef and cabbage; saverkraut with ham and sausage, cathan and hush puppies Or take Pennsylvania Dutch apple pie, containing frosh apples, black walnuts and raisins. The apples and walnuts would ripen together in the late fall, but fresh grapes would long since have gone; only dried grapes would be on hand as **TAISINS**

Recently my wife had to take off for Washington on family concerns, leaving me to do the cooking in her absence. Like any prudent husband, I studied the contents of the refrigerator before doing any substantial food shopping. The vegetable drawer yielded the following items: 1 pound zucchini, 1/2 pound fresh mushrooms and 1/2 basket cherry tomatoes. All needed to be used promptly if they weren't to spoil. Further rummaging produced some mozzarella cheese, some Parmesan cheese and a box of bread crumbs. These seemed like promising materials for a little Italian-style cooking. They turned into one of the best casseroles I have eaten in a long time. Here's my recipe. 1 Cut 1 pound zucchini in 1/4-inch slices, spread out on paper towel, sprinkle liberally with salt and let stand about 1 hour to draw out liquid. Blot dry with another paper towel. 2 Meanwhile with damp paper towel wipe off about 1/4 pound mushrooms; slice and set aside. 3 In large skillet add just enough olive oil to coat bottom (about 2 tablespoons): heat, then quickly brown zucchini; transfer to 1-quart casserole. 4 Add more oil to skillet if necessary and sauté mushrooms and 1 tablespoon minced onion just a few minutes until golden; spoon over zucchini in casserole. 5 Using about 1/2 basket cherry tomatoes, cut tomatoes in half and arrange over mushrooms. (One large tomato, sliced, or well-drained canned tomatoes may be substituted.) 6 Season casserole with 1 clove garlic, minced, 1/2 teaspoon Italian seasoning herbs and salt and pepper to taste.
7 Cut about 3 ounces mozzarella cheese in strips and layer over tomatoes.
8 Sprinkle with 3 tablespoons bread crumbs, then 1 tablespoon Parmesan cheese and a dash of paprika.
Making homemade jams and jellies with MCP® Pectin is both funand easy. For best results, it is important to always follow these guidelines:
- . Do not reduce the amount of sugar called for in the recipe. The exact amounts of sugar, fruit, acid and pectin are necessary for a good set.
- . Do not double recipes; mixture may not set.
- . Use ripe fruit for best flavor and color.
- . Crush, grind or finely chop all fruit thoroughly.
- . Always add pectin before the sugar.
- . A full rolling boil is a boil that does not stop when stirred.

Assemble the following pieces of equipment before starting to make jam or jelly:
- For cooked jams and jellies: half pint (8 ounce) or pint (16 ounce) glass jelly jars
- . For freezer jams and jellies: plastic containers (8 ounce) with tightfitting lids
- . Glass or plastic liquid measuring cup with pour spout for fruit pulp and other liquids
- . Metal or plastic dry measuring cup with straight top edge for sugar
- . Bowls for preparing fruit and premeasuring sugar
- . For jellies: MCP® Juice Extracting Kit or colander and cheesecloth
- . Use standard measuring cups and level measures for all ingredients,
- . If a little short of juice for jellies, add up to 1/2 cup water.
TO PREPARE CONTAINERS: Rinse clean plastic containers and lids with boiling water.
Berries and Grapes: Wash fruit. Stem and seed, if necessary. Grind or crush thoroughly until reduced to a pulp. Sieve 1/2 of the pulp to remove some seeds, if desired.
Other Fruit: Wash. Peel figs, kiwis or peaches. Pit, slice and grind or finely chop.

- 1. MEASURE prepared fruit and lemon juice, if called for, into large bowl. Measure sugar into separate bowl. Set aside. Gradually stir 1 package MCP® Pectin into fruit; mix thoroughly. Set aside 30 minutes, stirring every 5 minutes to dissolve pectin thoroughly.
- 2. POUR corn syrup into fruit mixture; mix well. This prevents sugar crystallization during freezer storage.
- 3. STIR in sugar gradually. Continue stirring to dissolve completely.
- 4. POUR into containers to within 1/2 inch of tops. Wipe off edges of containers; cover with lids. Freeze.

Wash, stem and crush or finely grind strawberries.
- 1. Measure prepared pulp and lime juice into large saucepan. If short of fruit pulp, add water
- 2. Slowly stir in 1 package of MCP Pectin and mix thoroughly. Set aside for 30 minutes, stirring every 5 minutes to dissolve pectin completely.
- 3. Add light Karo corn syrup and mix well. This prevents sugar crystallization during freezer storage. Stir in rum.
- 4. Add premeasured sugar gradually. Stir well to dissolve completely. Warming to 100°F (baby bottle temperature) will hasten dissolving. No hotter, please.
- 5. After sugar is thoroughly dissolved, pour into containers and seal.
6. Store freezer jam in freezer. Refrigerate after opening.

transcription: NUT BRITTLE SQUARES Use any kind of nuts you choose for this crisp, crunchy candy. Butter the outside bottom of an 8"square pan and sprinkle evenly with 1. cup rather finely chopped Brazil nuts, filberts, California walnuts, pecans, peanuts or other nuts. Set pan nut-side up on a tray. Put 1 cup sugar in heavy skillet and heat, stirring until golden brown and syrupy. At once pour evenly over nuts. When slightly cooled, remove in one piece to a board and cut in 2" squares. Makes 16 squares, or 1/2 pound.

**1.** The day before making tamales, stir together masa, shortening, baking powder, salt and water in a large bowl until combined. (Add additional water as needed. It should be about the consistency of peanut butter.) Cover with a damp towel and refrigerate for at least 8 hours. 2. Remove masa from refrigerator and knead to soften. Spread about 1/3 cup masa on the upper half of each corn husk; top with equal amounts of cheese, poblano and a sprinkle of jalapeños. Fold in sides and bottom of husk; tie the folded end with small strips of corn husk to secure, if you like. (Tamales may be frozen at this point for up to 3 months.)
3. Place folded end down in a steamer basket and cook, covered, for 1 hour. Remove from heat and let stand for 10 minutes before serving.

Also called Jerusalem artichokes, seasonal sunchokes are actually tubers that resemble fresh ginger. Homely on the outside, sunchokes' creamy, potato-like flesh is nutty and slightly sweet and supplies ample folate, fiber, and vitamin C, plus 28 percent of your daily iron needs per 1-cup serving. Peeling is optional, but wash thoroughly before using.

Mash. Dice peeled sunchokes into 1-inch chunks; add to a large pot of boiling water. Reduce heat and cook until tender, about 20 minutes. Drain and transfer to a bowl; mash until smooth and stir in butter or coconut oil. Season to taste; garnish with minced, fresh chives.

Roast. Slice sunchokes lengthwise into 1/4-inch pieces; coat with olive oil and sprinkle with minced garlic, salt, pepper, and dried rosemary. Roast at 425 degrees until easily pierced with a knife, 15-20 minutes.

- 2 cans (81/4 oz. each) pineapple chunks (reserve juice)

Mix loaf ingredients together thoroughly Press evenly into loaf pan. In a Soup 'R Mug or 1-cup measure, combine sugar, 1 table. spoon pineapple juice and mustard. Spread over loaf and sprinkle with remaining pineapple juice.
Place pan on Micro-GoRound® in over-Microwave at High 5 minutes. Reduce power to 50% (Medium). Microwave 23 to 28 minutes, or until loaf is firm and center is set (internal temperature 170°F).
Invert onto serving plate. Let stand, tented loosely with foil, 5 minutes.
- 1 green pepper, thinly sliced Hot cooked rice or chow mein noodles

Drain pineapple, reserving juice. Set aside pineapple. Add enough water to juice to make 11/3 cups liquid. In Mighty Pitcher combine liquid, brown sugar, cornstarch, vinegar and 1/3 cup soy sauce. Microwave at High for 71/2 to 11 minutes, or until mixture is thick and glossy, stirring twice with whisk. Set aside.

In medium mixing bowl, combine beef, pork, egg, 3 tablespoons soy sauce and bread crumbs. Mix well. Shape into 20 meatballs. Place meatballs and green peppers in 2-quart Oval Casserole in oven on Micro-Go-Round<sup>®</sup>. Microwave at High for 6 to 8 minutes, or until meat is no longer pink. Drain. Add pineapple chunks and sauce to meatballs. Microwave at High for 4 to 6 minutes, or until hot, stirring once. Serve over rice.
Breakfast in a Single Serving: Scrambled Eggs
Prepare in: Soup 'R Mug, Mighty Pitcher, 6" or 8" Skillet

Place butter in Soup 'R Mug or Mighty Pitcher. Microwave at High 30 to 45 seconds. or until melted. Add egg(s), milk, salt and pepper. Stir or whip with fork. Microwave one egg at High 35 to 45 seconds; two eggs 11/4 to 1% minutes, or until eggs begin to set, stirring with fork to break apart after half the time. Remove eggs when they are still soft and moist. Let stand about 2 minutes. Eggs will firm up while standing. If desired, sprinkle with shredded cheese during standing time.
While eggs are standing, place one strip of bacon between microwavable paper towels. Microwave at High 30 to 60 seconds. Crumble bacon and add to eggs.

Cut beef across grain into thin slices. Combine 1 tablespoon each cornstarch and soy sauce with sugar, ginger and garlic; stir in beef. Let stand 15 minutes. Meanwhile, remove flowerets from broccoli; if large, cut in half lengthwise. Cut stalks crosswise into  $\frac{1}{6}$ -inch slices. Combine remaining cornstarch and soy sauce with 1 cup water; set aside. Heat 1 tablespoon oil in wok or large skillet over high heat. Add meat and stir-fry 1 minute; remove. Heat remaining oil in same wok Add broccoli, onion and carrot; stir-fry 4 minutes, or until vegetables are tender-crisp. Stir in meat and soy sauce mixture; bring to boil. Cook and stir until sauce thickens. Serve immediately. Makes 4 servings.

Steak Diane is an ever-popular dish. Try this version with chicken breasts, slightly pounded for an interesting variation.
- 4 large boneless chicken breast halves or 8 small
- 3 Tbsp. chopped fresh chives or green onions
- Juice of  $\frac{1}{2}$  lime or lemon 2 Tbsp. brandy or cognac, optional
You can pound chicken breasts flat and leave flattened between sheets of plastic wrap. Wrap them airtight in one package and freeze for later use.
1 Place chicken breast halves between sheets of waxed paper or plastic wrap. Pound slightly with mallet. Sprinkle with salt and black pepper.

cooked and dry. Transfer to warm serving platter.

transcription: **SIMPLE SYRUP** Combine 11/2 cups granulated sugar and 11/4 cups water in saucepan. Stirring occasionally, bring mixture to boil over medium-high heat. Reduce heat; simmer, uncovered, 5 minutes. Remove from heat; cool in pan. Refrigerate in glass jar up to 1 month. Makes about 2 cups. **BLACKBERRY LIQUEUR Gently** wash 3 cups fresh blackberries; dry on towels. Place blackberries in glass container with tightfitting lid. Wash, dry, and remove peel from 1 lemon, scraping any white pith from peel. Add lemon peel to blackberries. Using wooden spoon, gently mash blackberries and peel. Add one 750-milliliter bottle vodka; stir and seal jar. Place in cool, dry spot away from sunlight. Let sit 2 weeks, swirling occasionally. Add 1% cups Simple Syrup (see recipe above). Stir again; reseal. Let sit 2 more weeks. Strain liqueur through double layer of 100% cotton cheesecloth into pitcher. Strain again through

transcription: This feathery cake is lovely served with ice cream or fresh fruit marinated in a liqueur. 3 cups cake flour or 2-3/4 cups all-purpose flour 1 teaspoon baking soda 1/4 teaspoon salt 6 eggs, separated 2 cups sugar, divided 1 cup butter or margarine, softened 2 teaspoons grated lemon peel 2 tablespoons lemon juice 1 cup plain yogurt Stir together flour, soda and salt; set aside. In large bowl of mixer beat egg whites until soft peaks form. Gradually add 1/2 cup sugar, beating until stiff but glossy peaks form; set aside. Beat butter, remaining 1-1/2 cups sugar, egg yolks, lemon peel and juice until fluffy. Stir flour mixture alternately with yogurt into creamed butter mixture, then gently fold into egg-white mixture. Pour into greased 10-inch plain or fluted tube pan. Bake in preheated 350° oven 50 to 60 minutes or until pick inserted in center comes out clean. Cool in pan 10 minutes, then turn out on rack to finish cooling. Serves 12.
cups All-Bran cereal cups low-fat milk cup corn oil large egg

Beat together cereal, milk, oil and egg with electric mixer. In separate bowl, mix flour, sugar, baking powder and salt. Add dry ingredients to bran mixture and stir until well mixed. Stir in apple, raisins and cinnamon. Pour into greased muffin tins and bake at 400 degrees 20 to 25 minutes or until muffins have risen and are golden. Makes 12 muffins.
